awd_titl_txt: iGEM Program at the University of Virginia
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will support the efforts of a team of undergraduate students from various STEM disciplines at the University of Virginia. The team will design and assemble a prototypical biological device for the International Genetically Engineered Machines (iGEM) competition in synthetic biology. The development and production of this device will provide undergraduate students with hands-on training in a variety of scientific areas, including synthetic biology, molecular biology and computational modeling. Broadening participation in STEM research is an important goal of this project. 

This project supports the interdisciplinary research training of a diverse team of undergraduate students at the University of Virginia. The team will design and produce a prototypical biological device for the International Genetically Engineered Machines (iGEM) competition in synthetic biology. The participants will receive training in a variety of STEM disciplines, acquire a global perspective on innovation and strategic road mapping, and have many opportunities to network with leaders in STEM fields such as synthetic biology, molecular biology and computational modeling.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award supported undergraduate student participation in synthetic biology research at the University of Virginia, in the context of an international synthetic biology competition known as iGEM (International Genetically Engineered Machines).  A diverse cohort of twelve students from multiple STEM fields participated in 2022 and received hands-on training in one or more STEM fields beyond their academic major, which resulted in a) the introduction of students to synthetic biology, a relatively new STEM field at the interface of the life sciences and engineering; b) technical and technical communication cross-training of students, in a team work-dependent environment, across STEM fields, resulting in improved labor force training that prepares students to be part of the expanding and evolving bio-economy or to be competitive for advanced educational opportunities in fields emgerging at the the interfaces of STEM disciplines; c) the introduction of students to both regional and global STEM communities, resulting in networking with peers and professional role models, creating a new awareness within students that competition for scientific and technical superiority on the global stage requires continuous innovation and strategic roadmapping; d) the opportunity for eight women as well as under-represented minorities in STEM to access research in synthetic biology; and e) direct encounters with a global biotech start-up community based on synthetic biology, introducing students to the possibilities and realities of entrepreneurship.

This award enabled technical innovation, wherein student participants designed a rapid, low cost, point-of-care, lateral-flow assay, analogous to a COVID home test kit, for the detection of early stage atherosclerosis, i.e., plaque build-up in arteries that can lead to heart attack and stroke. Atherosclerosis afflicts 25-30% of the global population. In early stages, if detected,  there is potential to reverse the disease.  In the time preiod of the award, the application of synthetic biology methods enabled the design, genetic build, and initial test production of several custom antibody-like molecules needed for the assay.
